Award.AwardTitle: Homological Methods and Tilting Theory of Finite Dimensional Algebras
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "Homological Methods and Tilting Theory of Finite Dimensional Algebras" will be held at The University of Iowa on August 16-19, 2019. The meeting will be a main event for researchers in the field of representation theory of finite dimensional algebras, with special focus on homological methods. Homological and categorical methods, including tilting theory, have had a great impact on representation theory of finite dimensional algebras and many of the main conjectures of the field have a homological flavor. The conference will include both talks by experts on recent progress and new approaches to open questions, and talks by early-career researchers about their research.

The meeting will bring together experts in representation theory and related fields, as well as early-career mathematicians, especially postdocs and graduate students. One goal of the meeting is to introduce participants to the latest directions in tilting theory and categorical methods, as well as new ideas and progress on homological conjectures, via expository talks by senior mathematicians that will be accessible to graduate students. The conference will provide a dynamic atmosphere encouraging interactions between leaders in the field and early-career mathematicians and PhD students, and the schedule will provide ample time for discussions and forging new collaborations. Details of the conference are available at the website http://homepage.divms.uiowa.edu/~miovanov/Homological-Methods.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference "Homological Methods and Tilting Theory of Finite Dimensional Algebras" supported by NSF funding 1904770 was successfully organized on August 16-19, 2019 at The University of Iowa. 

Intellectual merits

The conference aimed to help US students and young researchers to learn the current developments in the field of homological methods and tilting theory of finite dimensional algebras as well as recent progress on some homological conjectures, and encourage interactions between them and the established researchers in the field. It also brought together experts in various related fields, to improve communication and develop of new ideas on current and active research questions.

For specific examples, Jerzy Weyman and Oana Veliche gave two consecutive talks on new results about free resolutions over commutative algebras. The second speaker motivated a new conjecture on minimal free resolutions of ideals over regular local rings. Osamu Iyama, one of the leaders of representation theory, gave an inspiring talk about radical layers of representable functors which was developed by Kiyoshi Igusa and Gordana Todorov in 1984, with both of them also at the audience. He generalized the original theory in a more general setting with an easier proof. Van Nguyen showed a result about existence of some tilting modules related with the dominant dimension of the algebra and an application of the result in determining the finiteness of finitistic dimension for certain algebras, providing new  ideas about the long time finitistic dimension conjecture.

Broader Impact

The conference created a friendly atmosphere for communications between young and senior researchers, and contributed to the start of several collaborations. It hosted over 40 participants, among whom over 25% were graduate students, another about 25% postdocs and young researchers. Among the participants, we 33% were either women or belong to historically underrepresented groups or to people with disabilities. 

For specific examples, Ralf Schiffler, a well-known expert in representation and cluster algebra gave an expository talk on cluster category, a topic which has been widely studied by mathematicians in recent years and a less known realization of cluster category using duplicated algebras. Then Jonathan Rachowicz, a graduate student at Brandeis University talked about his work on new continuous cluster category, which is a variation of the classical cluster category. Ellen Kirkman, a well known professor in representation theory and homological algebra, delivered a talk about bounds on degrees of minimal generators of invariants, which is an important question in the invariant theory for finding generators and dates back to E. Noether's work in early 20th century. Then Francesca Gandini, a graduate student from Michigan University gave a talk on Noether's degree bound over the exterior algebra.

The conference provided opportunities of training and professional developments for young researchers. For example, Emily Gunawan met with two of her collaborators Emily Banrard and Ralf Schiffler at the conference and gave a talk about their project on Cambrian combinatorics, which helped them to organize the results and publish the preprint later this year.

In summary, the conference "Homological Methods and Tilting Theory of Finite Dimensional Algebras" was well attended and well received by the participants, and has fulfilled its goals of bringing senior and beginning researchers together and fostering a friendly atmosphere which encouraged interactions and new collaborations.
